For many families today in modern society, they no longer live with or close by to extended family members. This can be challenging especially when you are welcoming a new baby into the world. In many cultures traditionally the mother was kept indoors and catered to intently for this sacred time. Allowing her to heal, recover, bond, and welcome her new child. Sadly today this level of support is viewed as a complete luxury. Bia Don Dia is here to plan an important role in our community. Supporting the person & their family during the early weeks of postpartum.
Risks & Challenges
If we don't meet our goal things could take a little longer to complete as we will have to get the funding elsewhere. ie August could become September. Either way, this is happening and we are very excited!

Other Ways You Can Help
Some people just can’t contribute, but that doesn’t mean they can’t help! Help us get the word out. Tell your friends about Bia Don Dia and let them know they personally can help support families in San Francisco and the Bay Area. Also, feel free to share this around on social media!

story:
Short Summary

  • My name is Darius Smith. I am an engineer by education and an IT consultant by trade because I love dealing with people and business. I have worked for startups and I have done other entrepreneurial ventures previous to the Bark Park, but this is by far the most beneficial work I’ve done for a community.
  • I recently moved to Indianapolis from Las Vegas in late 2017. My doberman ‘King’ was used to warm weather 75% of the year and our cold months had no snow. As my wife and I got used to changes in the climate we had to help King adjust. We searched for a way to allow him to play and run in the winter time, but nothing fit our needs exactly how we expected. We made it through that winter, but this year I’ve dedicated time to finding a solution for our new city. We plan to have the first Indoor location for dogs all over Indy to come this winter and to continue to come all year around.
  • There are over 2 million people living in metro Indianapolis and surrounding areas and it is estimated that over 35% of us have dogs as pets. That means out of the 700,000 dog owners in town I am probably not the only one who has come across this problem. Based on the response I’ve gotten in the short amount of time, there are a lot of locals who are extremely excited to see us open our doors to the Indy pet community. We are going to be a place that makes a difference this year.

What We Need & What You Get

  • The benefit of supporting us early is that you will get to come and play but at a discounted price. Prices during the crowdfunding will be 20%-50% less than post launch prices.
  • Certain perks will also be come with other dog product gifts from other local business partners. For example some of our partners include: Paws and Play Dog Resort, Pet Wants Indy, Three Dog Bakery Indy, City Dog Grocery and many more. With each membership option,  you get at least one or more free gifts from of our local partners.
  • Lastly we plan to invite many of our backers to our VIP Grand Opening Party where you will be able to experience The Bark Park first before it is open with all of the other backers in the community.
  • We need $15,000 in upfront funding and here is why. We have found the perfect location! It is right across the street from the Castleton Square Mall at 5601 E. 82nd Street. The building is mostly ready for us, but the two things we have to upgrade:
  1. Clean and texturize the floors indoor to ensure that we all have a safe and sanitary place to play.
  2. We need to build a restroom inside so that the only potty mistakes are made by our four-legged friends.
  3. In addition to fixing up our building, we have:

- a downpayment for our lease.

- Insurance to make sure any accident is covered

- Decorations to make your new hangout look impressive

- And of course the equipment and toys! We plan to have a lot of activities available

The Difference

  • When I tell the story of why Indy’s Indoor Bark Park came to me, a lot of people tell me this business already exists and go on to mention the doggy daycare they take their dog to. This is the biggest hurdle people have when it comes to understanding our Indoor Bark Park. It is NOT a daycare where you drop off your dog and come back at a later time. We are a community-like destination for you come in and play along with your dog and everyone else’s dog as well. We are a place you can go and find great products and information dog lovers love to share. We are a place to go to enjoy and afternoon, evening or weekend. And we are the place you go to throw your dog a birthday party!
  • We already have the stamp of approval from many of the local businesses you already know and love. We have a location that is accessible for so many Indy dog parents. We have the logistics worked out for you to be able to come and enjoy more than just our dog park services but also the community of dog loving people.

Challenges

  • Challenge 1: We know people will come to visit the Bark Park in the peak of the summer and winter but we think attendance will be less incentivized in the spring and fall when there is less extreme weather.

Our solution for this challenge is to continue to grow year around and bring more and more value so that the Bark Park is not just a seasonal destination but a part of the community that people go to because your dogs don’t want to be anywhere else. When it is nice out, we will bring other human amenities such as craft beer, food trucks, TV's with live sports etc...  In other words you will have a list of reasons to come in addition to it being your dog's favorite place.

  • Challenge 2: Location.

We know people from all over Indianapolis and all of its suburbs will want the Bark Park to be in the neighborhood. Our main goal was to make sure we are located inside of the circle. We did the best we could to try to put it near many of the people who have been early supporters with the thought that they are a small sample size of who will eventually be our clientele. The location is near many highly populated areas of the city people enjoy. It is also near a 465 freeway exit so it is accessible to the entire town.

  • Challenge 3: Size of building.

We want there to be unlimited space for dogs to run as they have at an outdoor dog park. While that would be ideal, inside is a bit more challenging. Right now we are going to be leasing about 4,000sf of a facility. If we grow at the rate we expect, we should be able to max out the entire facility which will be more than double the space. This is solely dependent on how many dogs we continuously have visiting. There is a conjoined space next to our space that we plan to hopefully occupy because we've grown so large so fast. If we have enough dogs we will be able to rent both spaces and have an abundance of running and playing room. While we are still a small and new business we will rent what we can afford which is still a lot of space.

Other Ways You Can Help

  • Spread the word! We are new to Indianapolis so only a small percentage of people know we are starting this so far. We want every dog parent in town to know our name. You can tell a friend to tell a friend. You can invite people to visit us. You can come yourself and take pictures and post to your social media page.
  • The best thing you can do other than backing our campaign is to follow us on all social media platforms and share this campaign using the share buttons on this page. Below are our pages and make sure you Share! Share! Share! We can’t thank you enough.

Website

Facebook

Instagram

Twitter

story:
Matt here! Too Many Records, formerly known as Damnit Sandy, has been a YouTube channel since 2015. The content was mostly me sharing my growing and morphing collection of records in the form of rarities, recommendations and oddities across all genres and eras. I also try to make videos showing off record stores as often as possible, because they are cultural institutions that don't get enough love. 

Since the inception of “Too Many Records,” the channel has steadily grown to over 40,000 subscribers, and I have continued to branch out in many exciting ways. I started a record label, where I was able to help artists I love and believe in get their music on vinyl whereas they may not have been able to otherwise. We've sold out 12 releases in the span of two years. I also threw “Too Many Records Fest” (highlight reel linked) in March of 2019 in Los Angeles where I had 3 bands play, a live podcast, and ran a pop up shop selling 1000 highly curated records from my own collection to my fans. Over 300 people showed up, and it was an unforgettable day. It was that moment where I thought, "Man, I'd really love to own a record store one day" - and ideally one that would have a space for artists to perfom; like TMR Fest, but as a constant fixture. 

I’ve been thinking about the end game of Too Many Records. What is my ultimate goal? What have I worked towards over all these years, putting out content consistently and building these communities within our larger community. The record label is amazing, but that’s just the start of it. I’ve been inspired by stores big, and small, and how they can be cornerstones of their communities. I want to be a part of my community, and this is a way to use my passion and expertise to be a worthy addition. I'm doing this in partnership with my friend Roland, who has been a member of the TMR community for many years now, and is a Portland local. He's proven himself to be a great friend over the years, and I have full confidence that our partnership will give birth to a store that will fit right in with the legendary and admirable ones that currently exist in the area. 

Roland and I would be honored if you would help us get our dream off the ground. Below, we will explain the ethos behind the store, and our philosophy about how to make it awesome, as well as tell you about the perks you can get for supporting us!

 

We have enough funding to get the store going, but it will certainly be a bumpy ride. We're hoping that, with these rad perks, we'll be able to generate enough support from the community to assist us in polishing the rocketship in prep for take off, and unleash this beast into the world as beautiful as it can be.

We're asking for $25,000, which will help provide a runway for our monthly rent that will be coming in hot as soon as we open, as well as allow us to bolster the store's stock with a few more collection buys before we open the gate to a digger's paradise. 

The video on this page explains all the perks available to you, and you can also click through them on the side to get more information. If you have questions about any of them, please don't hesitate to reach out to us!

 

The world is moving further and further away from tactile things and in person experiences. The reason that so many of us love vinyl records is that they temporarily transport us into another world that's enhanced by the ritual of putting a record on, allow us to admire the art and liner notes, and appreciate owning a physical manifestation of a cherished album.

It's easy to buy a record on the internet. It's more fun to buy one in real life. We've spent the better part of our 20's and 30's going in and out of record stores around the world: they've become a second home. Becoming a part of the vibrant music community in Portland, OR is something we are elated and honored to have a chance to do.

If you're a local, you will have another home away from home. A welcoming and warm place to chat music, listen to some good tunes, and dig for your next uncovered treasure.

If you're not local, you will still be able to benefit from the store. Through Too Many Records, I spent 7 years building a community around my passion, knowledge, and taste in the music world. That level of dedication and respect will be a cornerstone of the store's operations, for both digital and in person efforts.

Another important factor as to why we decided on a brick and mortar versus a digital experience is that we are planning on putting a stage in the store. Local artists can sometimes struggle to find a place to showcase their music, and Too Many Records strives to be a destination for them to workshop things they're still figuring out, or play things that they're already proud of and have put into the world. This resource for the community, we hope, will be invaluable.

 

Starting a small business is daunting at any point in life, but especially at a time like this. With pandemic related uncertainties looming, the early stage of the store has potential to be a bit dicey. While we have a robust and desirable collection of records (across all genres and eras) to start off with, the longevity of the store depends on finding new and interesting collections to buy, and having the funds to do so.

What provides us with comfort is that many stores pivoted to online sales during the chaos of last year, and found a lot of success with those strategies. We plan to utilize the online community that Too Many Records has built as much as we can in conjunction with marketing efforts in the local community.

Any support you can provide us with will help reduce some of these fears and let our excitement take the wheel, which is the only way this endeavor can be as amazing as we anticipate it being. 

 

If you don't have the funds to help, that's okay! You can help by spreading the word about the store. Any shares of this crowdfund on socials or forums that you go to would mean the world in helping get the word out. 

Let's make the next great record store, together.

story:
Short Summary

Everyone deserves the opportunity to survive and grow, regardless of COVID-19 or inequitable access to resources.

MAKEHERS is a program empowering women in small business disproportionately impacted by COVID-19 in Sacramento through direct investment and advancing their entrepreneurial skills. By chipping in to our 60-day women's small business accelerator with direct funding, you can help directly support the growth of women-owned small businesses in #Sacramento.
⁠⁠
"Women have been particularly hard hit during the pandemic," said program manager Gina Lujan. "There has been so much focus on high-growth startups that we have lost sight of the micro-businesses in our region."

Nationally, 30% of women-owned businesses closed during the pandemic as compared with 17% of men owned businesses. MAKEHERS will empower, guide, and mentor underserved women entrepreneurs with holistic support through the ideation and seed stages of their endeavors.

Through this program, our team is offering direct resources to women entrepreneurs through seed funding, emergency funds and direct support that help women overcome the obstacles they are facing.
⁠
#SacramentoProud #SmallBusinessSacramento

Why we're asking for your help


Hi there, my name is Gina Lujan and I was 21 when I first started my own business out of necessity. I was a young mom, Latina and had to hustle. I know the struggle facing women-owned business owners because I am one. So when the pandemic hit, my heart went to the mothers (and women) called home from the workplace who wanted to start or had to close their own business but were hampered by the global pandemic facing all of us.

  • Many small business owners have closed down due to the coronavirus. Women entrepreneurs, in particular, have faced an economic disaster. 
  • Individuals also lost their pre-pandemic jobs. Micro-businesses are popping up as an alternative to a 9-5, with many earning a living making at home or reselling on Etsy and Facebook Marketplace. 
  • It was an answer and a solution to find a side-hustle. Now we need to help those intrepid entrepreneurs flourish and survive through this crisis.
  • By supporting small business, invest in yourself by receiving access to our exclusive perks and partnerships. Donate to women and take classes, or give a membership to a friend.

In addition, small businesses owners have had to pivot due to the crisis. This program also serves them: Supporting women in their business venture, or supporting women who have been forced to reinvent themselves. 

What We Need & What You Get

We need $15,000 for need-based incidentals (from bus passes to laptops) that are roadblocks for women entrepreneurs to support women entrepreneurs fully and holistically.

The MAKEHERS first cohort is already funded to serve 15 people with a $1,000 no strings seed investment for successful participants.

Supporters of the MAKEHERS program will be investing in rebuilding our economy. They will support local small businesses and help re-solidify the American dream for many and come back from one of worst recessions in our country's history equitably and fairly.

In addition, supporters will receive access to:

  • Stickers, bags, T-shirts, mugs and other merchandise;
  • Inspiring updates on the entrepreneurs' success;
  • An opportunity to attend MAKEHERS events and pitch nights;
  • Gift Hacker Lab classes and memberships;

Women entrepreneurs in the MAKEHERS program will receive as participants:

  • 60-day program offering a holistic business startup curriculum, tech fundamentals for business, marketing and ways to grow during the pandemic;
  • Mentorship and peer resources, including wellness and healing circles; 
  • Access to shared 24/7 community workspace at Hacker Lab;
  • Seed-funding upon successful graduation;
  • Access to classes, workshops, tool and equipment at Hacker Lab;
  • Navigation to community resources,

This program is already partially funded, so future funds will go to supporting the women, a larger emergency relief fund and future cohorts.

The Impact

3 million women have left the workforce due to the coronavirus.  (since COVID)

Over the past 9 years, at Hacker Lab we've served many of the people facing this crisis. As a community makerspace and workforce development incubator, we've personally mentored thousands of startups in the Sacramento region. 

During the pandemic, our team has helped hundreds of entrepreneurs through direct mentorship with the Sacramento Inclusive Economic Development Center.

Over the past year, we've built capacity through our Pathways program, which offers 8-months of access to our space to ambitious entrepreneurs from underserved communities. In our first pilot program, we helped 43 of 57 participants towards their goals of entering a new field, starting a new business or furthering an existing one, or attending higher education. 

We've found that if you give people the opportunity, they will return the investment tenfold. We've seen people make transformative change in their careers, education and small businesses, launching micro-businesses during the pandemic, learning to code, starting small businesses and selling their first $1,000 of products; and more.

Risks & Challenges

Our hurdles and challenges are that we must meet every entrepreneur where they are at. We may not have all the tools they need to succeed. They will be in different phases. Meeting them where they are at and having enough funds to help them is our core challenge.

However, through giving them access to our tools, as well as our extensive network of government, education and job-industry partners and experts, we are confident we can provide significant support — the seed and soil these entrepreneurs need, today. 

That's why we are pursuing a small-dollar donation campaign, by the people of Sacramento, to help our neighbors who have been hurt disproportionately by the pandemic. 

The more support you can give, the more aid we can provide to these participants.

(supporting also helps with recovery of our economy) (rebuilding and investing) (rebuild Sacramento)

Other Ways You Can Help

Can you help share this campaign with someone who would support it? Let's help women entrepreneurs who need it. 

Please use the Indiegogo share tools to help us make some noise!

Individuals also lost their pre-pandemic jobs. Micro-businesses are popping up as an alternative to a 9-5, with many earning a living making at home or reselling on Etsy and Facebook Marketplace. 
It was an answer and a solution to find a side-hustle. Now we need to help those intrepid entrepreneurs flourish and survive through this crisis.
By supporting small business, invest in yourself by receiving access to our exclusive perks and partnerships. Donate to women and take classes, or give a membership to a friend.

In addition, small businesses owners have had to pivot due to the crisis. This program also serves them: Supporting women in their business venture, or supporting women who have been forced to reinvent themselves. 

What We Need & What You Get

We need $15,000 for need-based incidentals (from bus passes to laptops) that are roadblocks for women entrepreneurs to support women entrepreneurs fully and holistically.
The MAKEHERS first cohort is already funded to serve 15 people with a $1,000 no strings seed investment for successful participants.
Supporters of the MAKEHERS program will be investing in rebuilding our economy. They will support local small businesses and help re-solidify the American dream for many and come back from one of worst recessions in our country's history equitably and fairly.
In addition, supporters will receive access to:

Stickers, bags, T-shirts, mugs and other merchandise;
Inspiring updates on the entrepreneurs' success;
An opportunity to attend MAKEHERS events and pitch nights;
Gift Hacker Lab classes and memberships;

Women entrepreneurs in the MAKEHERS program will receive as participants:


60-day program offering a holistic business startup curriculum, tech fundamentals for business, marketing and ways to grow during the pandemic;

Mentorship and peer resources, including wellness and healing circles; 

Access to shared 24/7 community workspace at Hacker Lab;

Seed-funding upon successful graduation;
Access to classes, workshops, tool and equipment at Hacker Lab;

Navigation to community resources,

This program is already partially funded, so future funds will go to supporting the women, a larger emergency relief fund and future cohorts.

The Impact
3 million women have left the workforce due to the coronavirus.  (since COVID)
Over the past 9 years, at Hacker Lab we've served many of the people facing this crisis. As a community makerspace and workforce development incubator, we've personally mentored thousands of startups in the Sacramento region. 
During the pandemic, our team has helped hundreds of entrepreneurs through direct mentorship with the Sacramento Inclusive Economic Development Center.
Over the past year, we've built capacity through our Pathways program, which offers 8-months of access to our space to ambitious entrepreneurs from underserved communities. In our first pilot program, we helped 43 of 57 participants towards their goals of entering a new field, starting a new business or furthering an existing one, or attending higher education. 
We've found that if you give people the opportunity, they will return the investment tenfold. We've seen people make transformative change in their careers, education and small businesses, launching micro-businesses during the pandemic, learning to code, starting small businesses and selling their first $1,000 of products; and more.

Risks & Challenges
Our hurdles and challenges are that we must meet every entrepreneur where they are at. We may not have all the tools they need to succeed. They will be in different phases. Meeting them where they are at and having enough funds to help them is our core challenge.
However, through giving them access to our tools, as well as our extensive network of government, education and job-industry partners and experts, we are confident we can provide significant support — the seed and soil these entrepreneurs need, today. 
That's why we are pursuing a small-dollar donation campaign, by the people of Sacramento, to help our neighbors who have been hurt disproportionately by the pandemic. 
The more support you can give, the more aid we can provide to these participants.
(supporting also helps with recovery of our economy) (rebuilding and investing) (rebuild Sacramento)

Other Ways You Can Help
Can you help share this campaign with someone who would support it? Let's help women entrepreneurs who need it. 
Please use the Indiegogo share tools to help us make some noise!

story:
Short Summary

Hi friends,

This campaign is about supporting the growth and connection of community. In January 2020, I bought a piece of land in Bastrop, TX with the vision of building a hub for health and family connection – named Bastrop Fitness Project. We are in the homestretch of developing this project and preparing to move three local businesses in to serve the community. In fitness, as in life, I have learned that asking for help makes the push across the finish line that much more possible and enjoyable. By supporting this indiegogo campaign, you would be contributing to the success of small business in Bastrop and providing fuel for us to serve the community where we live, work, and play. 

The Back Story

When the world was put on pause in March of 2020, I took it as a gift and an opportunity to locate and convene with existing and emerging business owners that shared my values and vision for transforming a building into a community destination – a place where friends and family would meet to pursue health goals and nurture their self-care practices.  

As 2020 went on, I had to come to grips with the realities of permitting, construction, and the rising cost of materials. Many small business owners will tell you that 2020 pushed us to the edge. For me, this meant navigating restrictions as a gym owner, asking for the partnership and patience of our tenants, and praying that all of our businesses could pivot and provide value long enough to outlast the pandemic.

How Your Invest Helps

The funds raised will support all of the businesses under the Bastrop Fitness Project and will be used in three main areas:

1. Expedite the Move

Here are some mock-ups of our new building! We will be located at 303 Martin Luther King Dr, Bastrop, TX, 78602. 


I’m THRILLED to be moving our gym to our own building, but what is even more exciting to me is that doing so will allow us to serve the Bastrop community in a more HOLISTIC way! We are experts in our modality, but we firmly believe that complete health must include restorative practices (like yoga) and work with your life (like childcare).

Over the past year, each small business in our collective has shouldered a number of additional and unforeseen costs as a result of COVID-19. On top of this – moving is stressful and expensive!

If we reach the $25,000 milestone, we will provide each tenant with a moving allowance that would allow them to hire additional hands or purchase additional resources to support their move and build out.

2. Offset Rent Increases

At the start of this endeavor, I worked hard to develop and design a building that could not only meet the needs of our small-businesses but also offered organic opportunities for the community to meet, connect and rejuvenate in our space. The pandemic not only extended our build-time but put us in a difficult position of figuring out how to finish the building during a time when material costs were rising at an unforeseen rate.

I have worked diligently to make decisions that don’t compromise the space for our partners and yet, the result of all of this meant marginal increases to all of our rent.

One of my highest priorities in this campaign to raise enough money to offset any rent increase for our small business partners (tenants) and be able to honor the original rent that they were offered.

The goal of $100,000 would allow us small business owners to move in September 2021 without passing on any additional costs which were incurred because of the COVID-19 pandemic and delays. 

3. Fund Community Scholarships

We are eager to grow roots, give back, and enhance the health of our neighbors. The last area of investment where we are seeking support is to start a fund which would allow us to underwrite community scholarships in each of our businesses.

With your help, for each $10,000 we raise, we will fully fund a community scholarship to one of our businesses to a neighbor within our own community!

Meet the Businesses

Bastrop Fitness Project will be home to 3 locally-grown businesses:

Strive Strength & Conditioning 

Our mission is to empower people to be happier, healthier, and more successful in life. We’re veteran-owned and community powered. Strive is a family first, a gym second. We coach you how to achieve your goals inside the gym so you can smash your goals outside of the gym. Whatever your health and fitness goals are, our professional coaches and supportive community will help you get there. We teach you, hold you accountable, and cheer you every step of the way. There are the people I'm proud to serve...

As we expand into the Bastrop Fitness Project, we will also be expanding our business model. Welcome Strive Human Optimization! Training hard means that you need to recover even harder. Training breaks you down and the only way to really achieve your goals is to allow your body to recover and adapt to the stress the training places on it. That’s why we are now adding a full recovery center that features hot saunas, cold plunge baths, and compression therapy. Progress in your goals just got easier! 

Body + Shine Wellness

At Body + Shine Wellness (BSW), we aim to make yoga (and related practices) approachable for everyone interested regardless of age, gender, or experience level. We create a fun, friendly, and supportive environment where everyone feels safe, welcome, and never judged. Our practice is light hearted and can fit any student willing to come to their mat. We acknowledge that yoga is a seriously life changing practice, but we remove common stigma and stereotypes and encourage people to enjoy the process.  

Our first location opened in Elgin in 2016, and we are excited to expand our community with our second location in Bastrop. We will be offering many types of yoga--including Power/Flow, Slow/Beginner Stretch, Restorative, cYoga, and even heated classes--along with meditation, Pilates, specialized workshops, teacher training programs, and more. We also offer classes online on demand and a virtual retail boutique so you can connect with us anytime, anywhere. 

Meet the Owner: 

My name is Katy Gassaway. After years of practicing yoga and meditation, in 2014, I decided to take a teacher training course while I waited to take the Texas Bar Exam. I quickly realized that sharing the practice of yoga with others made me happier and more fulfilled than practicing law or anything else ever had. As a serial small business owner for over a decade, it was inevitable I’d want to expand from our original Elgin studio, and I couldn’t have picked a better place than Bastrop. I am so excited to continue growing with this community!

Wild Child

At Wild Child, our mission is to prioritize fitness for local families. We provide a safe, fun, and healthy environment where kids ages 3 to 10 are encouraged to get their wiggles out through active play while parents work out. We combine fitness and fun for children by encouraging movement and energetic play on our giant indoor playground- no screens or TV’s! At Wild Child, we put the Wild back in the Child!

Meet the Owner:

My name is Lexi Grose. I am a young entrepreneur with a passion for fitness, health, and working with children. I have worked as a certified CrossFit coach/trainer at Strive Strength and Conditioning in Bastrop from 2019 through 2021. During my time coaching, I recognized that child care is often a barrier for parents trying to prioritize their own health and fitness. Working with children has always been a passion of mine, and I felt called to pursue this further. Wild child was born as an opportunity to serve the community while encouraging kids and adults to prioritize fitness, healthy living, and fun!

Slated time-line

While things may shift for various reasons, here is our tentative timeline. We will update these dates as milestones are hit and pieces of this move fall into place.

  • May 31st (MEMORIAL DAY) Indiegogo launch
  • July 2nd Indiegogo Campaign is fully funded!
  • September 1st Moving Begins
  • September 15th  Private opening tour for V.I.P. campaign backers**
  • September 30th Official opening
  • October 1st Begin production on campaign rewards
  • October 20th Shipments of campaign rewards prepped and packed
  • October 30th  All campaign rewards are shipped out

Other Ways You Can Help

Some people just can't contribute, but that doesn't mean they can't help! Please get creative and share our campaign with YOUR network in the following ways:

  • Do you have belong to a Bastrop Facebook group where you could share this campaign?
  • Does your church do weekly announcements?
  • Do you have a social media following?
  • Can you share this with your neighborhood or HOA?
  • Do you own a small business have a partnership idea?

And that's all there is to it.

story:
IKIKÉ’S FARMS: CROWDFEEDING CAMPAIGN

About the Founder

Hi, it’s Cheick Ahmed Toure. I’d like to thank you for taking time to swing by our campaign. For a little concerning me, I am the author of a few books (5), 1 written under my real name and the others under the nom de plume, Mosaid Ikiké. you can click here for my author profile. I own the agribusiness Ikiké’s Farms, which began by retailing coffee in my native country, Guinea.

The Agribusiness

The Goal of Ikiké’s Farms is to produce a variety of high-quality food, using modern agricultural methods. These will be sold at an affordable cost in impoverished nations. We plan on creating jobs in this lacking industry, by training workers and furthering their education through books, mentoring and affordable modern courses. Within the next 5-10 years, we plan on providing significantly in west African countries with Ikiké’s Farms produce.

We are to begin achieving this goal by working on land that is already available to us, which is close to 70, 000 square meters now (to be expanded). The first country where this will start is the one where we possess the most land, Guinea Conakry. It is a place with a population most recently reported as 14,000, 000 out of which over 2,000,000 are unsure of where their next meal will come from.

At some point, we all complained about world hunger. Some issues are complicated, we know. This is one of them. Yet the solution is quite easy. To eradicate famine, modern agricultural theories are way ahead of the current practices. Artificial methods of growth alone would suffice in reversing the current famine situation and there are numerous modern methods to speed up the production of food.

We don’t need to show statistics to make the assertion, that even though resources are finite, the ones we have are more than enough to feed the existing population and more. Although the growth of crops is cyclical we can speed the process up by using more land we can grow large quantities of food suited to certain areas, and by building storage facilities, we can effectively contribute to the already present sources of sustenance.

There are many industries that are indispensable; this is the one that needs the most attention. For a hungry person cannot tend to any higher pursuits.

In our business plan, we’ve accommodated a 20 percent donation margin. That means 2 out of 10 of everything we produce will go towards feeding impoverished communities, for free. The remainder of the profits will be re-engaged into the next harvest and in expansion projects (purchase of farmable land, hiring trained farmers, building storage, employee housing and barns).

This enterprise or cause is a chance for us to act. We have an essential resource for the project, LAND, but a financial impediment that prevents us from actualizing our vision. That’s where Indiegogo came into the picture for our project. We’re hoping that somewhere in the hearts of those who understand this campaign a little support will be found. We believe that the saying “we are stronger together”, is a fact, regardless of all else that is portrayed.

The next phase of Ikiké’s Farms’ vision is to produce staple food on an ongoing basis. This may seem ludicrous but hear us out. Our founding member, Cheick Ahmed Touré, a writer of 5 books, a final year business student and an autodidact who is fond of playing around with ideas, concocted one that is a viable solution, he calls it the Artificial Plantation TM. It is an environment that will produce staple food during the seasons in which nature does not facilitate their growth. It will mimic the season best suited to the growth of plants, regulated by software that is currently in design associated with a mechanism that will administer temperature, quality, and quantity of light and reproduce the effect of air, while duly irrigating the earth.

Now you may be thinking, “Oh don’t tell me about GMO’s?”. Well, we hope you aren’t because It’s part of the solution. Genetically modified food is a viable way of producing higher quantities of highly nutritious food and faster. That is something we plan to engage, in the foreseeable future. But the methods we’ve mentioned, have for thousands of years been used as the most reliable way to grow crops for human consumption.

THE NEED

The need here is not a gadget that is price-wise out of reach from the financially disadvantaged. The need here is something even the poorest of the poor should be able to afford, basic daily sustenance. This business and charitable endeavor will offer growing quantities of its produce (Starting from 20 %) to those who are not able to afford basic needs.

The needs of this enterprise, to get it up and running are minimal, yet costly, even in a country with a weak currency. That is why agriculture is least developed in such regions. However, beyond the cost of maintaining the business afloat and expanding its mission to make healthy food available to greater and greater numbers of impoverished communities at a cost that will be far below the current market prices.

There is another need, the need to feel like we’ve had a positive impact by being here on earth. This enterprise is a conduit for such efforts. The end goal is to offer good food at an affordable cost to less fortunate communities.

Everyone’s basic needs are fulfilled in this exchange. We truly hope this resonates with you on a human level. Money comes and goes but good deeds last far longer.

COST

The sum we are asking for is not much for such a campaign scale $100,000 dollars. We aren’t

asking to be given the cost of the entire enterprise. It will require more effort to scale things to

the level of our vision. As you may have wondered, how will this all be achieved with $100,000?

With such a sum we would be able to purchase:

  •  All the required seeds
  •  Manure/ Fertilisers
  •  Processing Machines
  •  Pesticides
  •  Ploughing Equipment, shovels…etc.
  •  Hire masons to make an Architecture plan and build the housing for employees
  •  Build fences around the land, the cattle, chickens, and other livestock.
  •  The construction material (bricks, planks…etc.)
  •  The livestock that will be raised for consumption.
  •  Maintain the livestock’ health and barns.
  •  The cleaning equipment to maintain the farm at large.
  •  Equipment to protect the workers (masks, gloves, working outfits, sanitisers)
  •  Hiring a security to keep the crops and cattle safe from potential thieves.
  •  Hiring the farmers who will tend to the crops
  •  Hiring the temporary aid among the villagers to collect the crops and help in transporting
  • them to storage
  •  A truck to transport the harvest to the selling point.
  •  Setting up a space in selected markets to sell the produce and distribute the allotted free portions to homeless children and adults.
  •  Bags and containers for the produce.
  •  Processing machines
  •  Begin part of the first Artificial Plantation.
  •  Purchase additional land to expand the initial 70, 000 square meters.

TIME

The duration for such a project to take place would be:

Crop Growing period:

  • Time to harvest
  • Time to distribute
  • Time to sell
  • Cattle growing period:
  • Copulation and Reproduction
  • Transportation to selling points
  • Duration to sell

For good measure, we’d like to factor in potential delays in the process due to external factors such as weather or transportation issues. Here’s a pie chart, to give you a visual idea of how funds will be allocated.

LET’S VISUALISE TOGETHER

Let’s imagine all we’ve said so far, fast forwarding a year into the future. We no longer see the mostly barren 70, 000 square meters of land, now it is occupied by plants of all kinds. We see the farmers working the land and taking care of the seeds that will begin an agricultural revolution within West Africa. We see this dream coming true because it is noble and worthy.

That is why you have paused for a second too, just like we did at the thought of Ikiké’s Farms’ potential; because you see what we’ve seen.

All that is left is to push this campaign towards its realization, one contribution at a time. One heart and soul’s blessing at a time. Now you know, what this could mean for impoverished regions such as Guinea and others. And you know, what to do to help us and join this agricultural revolution: CONTRIBUTE.

 

PS: we will be updating our contributors once or twice a week during the campaign, and once a month afterward for those who’d like to know about the project’s development, and may like to participate in other ways.

Extra!

You can email us at cheickahmedt@gmail.com if you’d like to give us feedback or discuss anything.

For the virtual tour, if you haven’t checked it out yet here’s a link https://thelocust.itch.io/ikikesfarmscampaign. 

Acknowledgement for the Ikiké's Farms Team

Thank you guys for your input and support all through out this project. I hope to work with you on numerous projects in the future.

THANK YOU FOR READING.

Sincerely Yours,

Cheick Ahmed Touré/ Mosaid Ikiké

Well, we hope you aren’t because It’s part of the solution. Genetically modified food is a viable way of producing higher quantities of highly nutritious food and faster. That is something we plan to engage, in the foreseeable future. But the methods we’ve mentioned, have for thousands of years been used as the most reliable way to grow crops for human consumption.THE NEEDThe need here is not a gadget that is price-wise out of reach from the financially disadvantaged. The need here is something even the poorest of the poor should be able to afford, basic daily sustenance. This business and charitable endeavor will offer growing quantities of its produce (Starting from 20 %) to those who are not able to afford basic needs.The needs of this enterprise, to get it up and running are minimal, yet costly, even in a country with a weak currency. That is why agriculture is least developed in such regions. However, beyond the cost of maintaining the business afloat and expanding its mission to make healthy food available to greater and greater numbers of impoverished communities at a cost that will be far below the current market prices.There is another need, the need to feel like we’ve had a positive impact by being here on earth. This enterprise is a conduit for such efforts. The end goal is to offer good food at an affordable cost to less fortunate communities.Everyone’s basic needs are fulfilled in this exchange. We truly hope this resonates with you on a human level. Money comes and goes but good deeds last far longer.COSTThe sum we are asking for is not much for such a campaign scale $100,000 dollars. We aren’tasking to be given the cost of the entire enterprise. It will require more effort to scale things tothe level of our vision. As you may have wondered, how will this all be achieved with $100,000?With such a sum we would be able to purchase:
 All the required seeds
 Manure/ Fertilisers
 Processing Machines
 Pesticides
 Ploughing Equipment, shovels…etc.
 Hire masons to make an Architecture plan and build the housing for employees
 Build fences around the land, the cattle, chickens, and other livestock.
 The construction material (bricks, planks…etc.)
 The livestock that will be raised for consumption.
 Maintain the livestock’ health and barns.
 The cleaning equipment to maintain the farm at large.
 Equipment to protect the workers (masks, gloves, working outfits, sanitisers)
 Hiring a security to keep the crops and cattle safe from potential thieves.
 Hiring the farmers who will tend to the crops
 Hiring the temporary aid among the villagers to collect the crops and help in transporting
them to storage
 A truck to transport the harvest to the selling point.
 Setting up a space in selected markets to sell the produce and distribute the allotted free portions to homeless children and adults.
 Bags and containers for the produce.
 Processing machines
 Begin part of the first Artificial Plantation.
 Purchase additional land to expand the initial 70, 000 square meters.
TIMEThe duration for such a project to take place would be:Crop Growing period:
Time to harvest
Time to distribute
Time to sell
Cattle growing period:
Copulation and Reproduction
Transportation to selling points
Duration to sell
For good measure, we’d like to factor in potential delays in the process due to external factors such as weather or transportation issues. Here’s a pie chart, to give you a visual idea of how funds will be allocated.LET’S VISUALISE TOGETHERLet’s imagine all we’ve said so far, fast forwarding a year into the future. We no longer see the mostly barren 70, 000 square meters of land, now it is occupied by plants of all kinds. We see the farmers working the land and taking care of the seeds that will begin an agricultural revolution within West Africa. We see this dream coming true because it is noble and worthy.That is why you have paused for a second too, just like we did at the thought of Ikiké’s Farms’ potential; because you see what we’ve seen.All that is left is to push this campaign towards its realization, one contribution at a time. One heart and soul’s blessing at a time. Now you know, what this could mean for impoverished regions such as Guinea and others. And you know, what to do to help us and join this agricultural revolution: CONTRIBUTE. PS: we will be updating our contributors once or twice a week during the campaign, and once a month afterward for those who’d like to know about the project’s development, and may like to participate in other ways.Extra!You can email us at cheickahmedt@gmail.com if you’d like to give us feedback or discuss anything.For the virtual tour, if you haven’t checked it out yet here’s a link https://thelocust.itch.io/ikikesfarmscampaign. Acknowledgement for the Ikiké's Farms TeamThank you guys for your input and support all through out this project. I hope to work with you on numerous projects in the future.THANK YOU FOR READING.Sincerely Yours,Cheick Ahmed Touré/ Mosaid Ikiké

story:
Mil Mundos Books is a bilingual bookstore and community center located in Bushwick, Brooklyn, that curates to celebrate Black and Latinx heritage and culture. Our mission, in brief, is to resist gentrification, empower community members, and to be a resource in a working class community, for the community that’s already here. Our founders are Latinx NYC natives fighting for our home.

While we are solidifying programming and resources for the community for the next year, unforeseen financial hurdles have severely limited our funding, jeopardizing its long term viability. Buildout came in $10,000 over budget, while only one of two SBA loans applied for came through, $10,000 below the requested amount. Nevertheless, we are committed to giving Mil Mundos a fighting chance.

So, our strategy is to generate revenue, reduce monthly overhead, and create sustainable revenue streams that will fortify the project going forward. Last week, we decided as a group to become an all-volunteer run space to help cut costs while it becomes more sustainable. This brings monthly overhead from roughly $8000 a month down to $3800 a month. Now, we are fundraising to generate capital for the space.

....
 

We are raising $50,000 to help us with the following:

  • $14,000 - remaining contractor balance owed from buildout
  • $6,000 - event equipment, shelving, office equipment to provide printing services to the community
  • $30,000 - six to seven months of overhead costs to give the project time to become sustainable

 

Our Impact

It has been several decades since there has been a general purpose bookstore that folks in eastern Bushwick can talk about having any sort of regular presence in their lives growing up, let alone a bookstore that also carries titles in the predominant language of the neighborhood. In a neighborhood where gentrification and displacement run rampant, a community resource by and for those who already call Bushwick home is invaluable. Mil Mundos tells our story, speaks our language, and provides for our needs. 

We want to partner with the 30+ schools in the Bushwick area to organize class trips to students' local bookstore. We want to host book fairs at local educational institutions that highlight narratives that community members can identify with. We want to host events that delve into unique and diverse experiences within Black and Latinx culture. We want to unite like-minded writers and publishers, and serve as a network point for folks to meet as they share their stories and the stories of others. With your help, we can do all of this, and so much more.

 

Our Mission Statement

Mil Mundos Books’ primary mission is to remain dedicated to larger-scale anti-gentrification work in eastern Bushwick and beyond, and to maintain a curation and space that celebrates Black and Latinx heritage and supports the narratives of these cultures. Our two strategies toward this end are:

1. Proactively engage with the community - especially with Black and Latinx communities adversely affected by incoming commerce - to maintain a two-way conversation about how best to encourage and support their autonomy and agency in their own neighborhood and lives.

2. Maintain a culture of acceptance, inclusivity, and healthy communication both within the store and as an organization overall, serving as a model of our commitment to our values in any work environment.

While we are currently organized as an LLC, it is our goal to eventually transition over to either a worker-owned business model or to a 501(c)(3) non-profit corporation. Any profits made after paying off debts and ensuring fair wages for those working the storefront on a daily basis will be reinvested into the community and furthering the mission of the space.

 

Other Ways You Can Help

There are other MAJOR ways you can help!

VOLUNTEER! If you over 18, live in the NYC area, and speak both English and Spanish, you can make a direct and immediate impact by helping make spaces like these more accessible to the neighborhood. Get involved in our collective process and fill out this form to get started: https://tinyurl.com/volunteeratmm.

EDUCATORS: we want to work with you directly. Interested in writing curriculums for schools based on the literature we prioritize? Or maybe you would like to work with us to organize a class trip to the shop, or a book fair at your school? We would love to hear from you! Email info@milmundosbooks.com to get the conversation started.

LEADERS: we are currently looking for folks who would like to get involved in our broader collective process. Our team right now is small but committed to our mission, and we are always open to working with others who share our passion for this project as well. If you are interested, you can also email info@milmundosbooks.com to schedule a time for us to all meet up!

SPREAD THE WORD! Share our campaign on social media, talk about it with your friends and neighbors, come by the store for a visit or a workshop! Planned upcoming workshops include:

  • soap making: learn how to make soap from ingredients in your kitchen that you love
  • candle making: learn how to make your own delicious candles at home
  • block carving: learn how to make wooden hand-carved block prints
  • fermentation lab: learn how to make kimchi, sauerkraut or pickled veggies

Thanks from all of us at Mil Mundos. With your support, we will keep this vibrant and crucial community resource alive for many years to come.

story:
A Little About Vernalicious

After feeding thousands of people at hundreds of events throughout Philly, we have decided to park the truck for the very last time and embark on a new adventure... a brick and mortar restaurant. Finally, you'll be able to step inside and sit down to truly enjoy a Vernalicious creation in the comfort of our new home. 

Over the years we have learned a lot about preparing simply good food and now, we are hungry to bring that skill to the next level.

We found a location - got the keys in fact! - and are proud to call South Philly our new home. Located just steps away from from the box stores along Columbus Blvd, the only boxes WE'LL have at our quaint Front & Ritner Sts location will be those we use for take away!

Our restaurant will feature a scrumptious menu of roasted chicken, pork and vegetable dishes. We'll offer ready-to-eat take-away meals as well as comfortable table service.  We are working on adding curbside pickup as well, to allow guests to grab meals to take home without having to find parking. Whatever we can do to spread that Vernalicious Love <3

The Vernalicious Mission

• To source the most natural, local, no-antibiotics, no growth hormones and no preservatives products available.
• For 25 years we have contributed tens of thousands of dollars (along with volunteer time) to several local non-profit organizations. We pledge to continue community support in our new venture.
• The restaurant will be an incubator and collaborative space to host local culinary talent in achieving their dreams. Look forward to exciting events and pop-ups with established and aspiring chefs, bakers, producers and makers. 

Our Segment on Eat Street

What We Need

As we get started, we will need money to get our restaurant up and running. 

The $50,000 goal is what we will spend to convert the space to suit the needs of our restaurant, including updates in the kitchen.  

What You Get

Fans of Vernalicious can help by contributing here! 

Perhaps you want to wear your love for Vernalicious on your sleeve ... which you can do with a new and nifty T-shirt or cap. If that's not your thing - help us get closer to our goal by reserving a meal or two in advance! Better yet, gather your friends and let's have a PARTY... a private party that I'll cater for you and nine of your best foodie friends! 

No matter what, we are making this happen.  If we don't meet the goal, we will find the rest of the funds to open the space, it just might take a few weeks longer before we can open the doors.

Here are some of the perks...

What This Means To Us

Your contribution to this campaign means the world to us.  We have met some incredible people over the years, making our journey so worthwhile.  In fact, those folks have made us so proud to be part of the incredible food scene in Philadelphia. We want to continue to share in what makes the community great.

Risks & Challenges

There are always unforeseen challenges in opening a restaurant, but the lease is already signed and we are already started getting the place ready to open

Other Ways You Can Help

If you can't contribute, you can always share this campaign with friends and family.  Spread the word.  Help us reach our goal even if you don't have the means to contribute. Support local businesses and local eats! 

Together, Let's Do This!

story:
The Impact

Our deepest passion is serving, showcasing and developing the most talented, influential and inspiring artists, visionaries and entrepreneurs our local community has to offer.

The space has two open levels and a back room for readings and treatments. The top level will be a formal gallery for presenting transformational and visionary art. The bottom level designed for comfort, connection and creation, home to events, circles and workshops.

We support radical self-acceptance through personal responsibility.

We are creating waves of change, growth, healing and evolution, rippling out into our families and ultimately the entire world around us.

Our Story

I am Aprilynn Noriega and I imagined the most practical way to create the largest impact in the development of healthy communities; gathering all the resources, direction and healing support that has been an essential part of my own journey to wellness.

Partnering with Sunny Freeman was a divine intervention, amplifying the magnitude of vision we had the potential to tap into. As a life long peace activist and grassroots community organizer, she has spared no expense in the pursuit of creating a better world. And as a phenomenal visionary artist herself showcasing these talents in others is a natural extension of her passion.

The synergy of our partnership has afforded us exponential progress, bringing this dream into tangible reality.

What We Need & What You Get

Your contribution directly impacts our ability to:

  • Expand our reach with marketing, web and social media development. Renovate and offer a quality space with comfort and appeal.
  • Diversify our calendar of events with valuable presentations particularly geared toward suicide prevention, body positivity, mental health awareness and reducing stigma, lgbtq+, consent culture, overcoming trauma, healthy touch, social activism, personal empowerment and creating meaningful connections.
  • Support healthy human development and healing in a variety of ways, including art, expression, workshops and personal sessions.

Overcoming Adversity

When I left all I had known and fought for as my 15 year marriage collapsed I was faced with utter and complete uncertainty for both myself and my the three children.  I took every step forward in complete faith though it most often felt like a long walk of a short plank. Guided by the gifts afforded me through my own awakening I have challenged the status quo at every turn, following my heart and my heart alone.  Never compromising my internal compass as my only authority has proven a saving grace. I wish to in turn help develop  this in others as they step into the sheer magnificence of the miraculous upon claiming their own spiritual sovereignty. 

The leap out of challenge and struggle toward security has been no different. With no guarantee of success and every risk of failure, I have persisted, determined to offer my children the quality of life they can thrive in, determined to show the world that their deepest longing is a heart song the world will match in effort.

Reclaiming our spiritual sovereignty individually and collectively as we learn to once again follow our heart's calling is the only answer to saving both ourselves and the very world around us. We are all already risking everything with in a world desperate for revolution. Everyone of us has to go all in.

Please help us ignite this fire in as large a scope as we can imagine. And if you don't feel inspired to invest in our dream, please, please at least consider writing down and fine tuning your own. 

Other Ways You Can Help

Your voice and intention has power. Please help us spread the word by sharing this campaign with your circle, however big or small. You can also sign up to our email list to keep up to date on the latest details and progress of Winging It!

story:
UPDATE: The Lev is actively campaigning on iFundWomen -- donate there.

Opened in February 2018, The Lev is a pop-up community bookstore for women and children located in Venice, Los Angeles. I founded The Lev for two main reasons:

  1. A community space for women: Without specifically intending to, most businesses are patriarchal. It is more important than ever that women have a community space for comfort and security.
  2. Promote women and people of color writers: Reading other peoples’ stories helps build empathy and understanding.

​

The Lev has brought together an amazing community of readers, connected online communities such as Girls at Library (GAL) and Mend by hosting over 20 author readings, talks, storytime & art hours, book swaps, workshops, monthly book clubs and other community events in only four months.

We’ve had the great pleasure of hosting artists, makers and writers such as Roda Ahmed, Mari Andrew, Trish Baden (Flores Lane), Katelynn Bartiromo, Danielle Birrittella (The Intuitive Voice),  Zinzi Clemmons, Lisa Cole (Hungry Right Meow), Yrsa Daley-Ward, Magdalena Edwards, Erin Falconer, The Fullest, Amy Harrison (The Little Studio LA), Aishwarya Iyer (Brightland), Mira T. Lee, Shira Lenchewski, MariNaomi, Laura Rubin (AllSwell), Yumi Sakugawa, Emily Stroia, Dydine Umunyana, Ally Walsh & Casey Wojtalewicz (Canyon Coffee), Jen Wang, Shinay Watts (Ellie and Sass), Stephanie Waxman, Meredith Westgate, Maude White, Women's National Book Association Los Angeles, and Fran Yang (Incandescent Bloom).

See our upcoming events here!

To prepare for opening The Lev pop up, I spoke with many booksellers across the country and even flew to a bookstore in Oklahoma City, Commonplace Books, to shadow owner Ben Nockels (to whom I am incredibly grateful) to learn about the journey of a community-focused bookstore. Many thanks to American Booksellers Association,  Books are Magic, Brazos Bookstore, The Dial Bookshop, Duende District, The Ripped Bodice, and Women & Children First for your generous advice ranging from the mundane to the magic of hosting our favorite writers. 

The Lev has served 600+ customers and processed more than 800 transactions but without the support of you and our community, The Lev will not flourish. Here are three main challenges we’re facing:

  1. Real estate in LA is extremely expensive. To open, The Lev shared spaces with amazing brands (many thanks to Linus Bike and boy+girl for supporting The Lev). However, for The Lev to fulfill its mission of serving as a community bookstore, we need our own space. As such, we’re opening the search for a long term home to include all of LA. Our hope is to still stay in Venice or the surrounding area.
  2. Financial solvency. Since rent will be high, The Lev will have tight sales goals. With The Lev membership program, we hope that our community will be loyal customers. However, The Lev plans to invest in a strategic marketing plan.
  3. The unexpected.  A part of the funds being raised is dedicated to having an operations reserve.

With your support, I am committed to making The Lev a long-term establishment. My goal is to open a new storefront by September. I already have author events planned for the fall.

“Without specifically intending to, most businesses are patriarchal, and as such, some bookstores are. For me, reading books is a comfort — I wanted to create a bookstore for women so that we have a place for comfort and security.” - Miriam Chan, Ideal Woman

Miriam Chan is the owner and founder of The Lev. She knows what it takes for a business to succeed. Prior to The Lev, Miriam helped grow operations at startup company Civis Analytics from 13 employees to 140+, and led western state operations on President Barack Obama's reelection campaign in 2012.  Miriam’s love for books started at an early age. Her fondest memories are of her parents taking her to the county library and local bookstore as a child. Her absolute favorite writers are Maggie Nelson and Jean Rhys but is currently crushing on Elaine Castillo and Lisa Halliday. When not in the bookstore, visiting local bookstores or supporting local LA businesses, Miriam practices yoga and is a certified yoga instructor from her training at Venice's Love Yoga.

    • If you don’t already, follow our Facebook, Instagram and mailing list for community updates!
    • Spread the word about The Lev — encourage others to follow us and to join our mailing list.
    • Share our campaign — if you refer 10 people, you’ll get a $10 gift card to The Lev! You must do this through Indiegogo’s sharing tools
    • Purchase books through The Lev — we can make special orders!  Email hello@thelev.co

    Our Venice pop up closes on Wednesday, June 27. As I campaign to raise funds, find The Lev at pop ups and markets around the city starting in July.

    Thank you so much for checking out The Lev's crowdfunding page! Please support The Lev in building a community around women and books, and raising awareness of women and people of color writers helping them have a platform to educate and influence the younger generation in a powerful way!

    If you have any questions, don't hestitate to email me miriam@thelev.co

    With love and heart,

    Miriam Chan
story_txt:
UPDATE: The Lev is actively campaigning on iFundWomen -- donate there.

Opened in February 2018, The Lev is a pop-up community bookstore for women and children located in Venice, Los Angeles. I founded The Lev for two main reasons:


A community space for women: Without specifically intending to, most businesses are patriarchal. It is more important than ever that women have a community space for comfort and security.

Promote women and people of color writers: Reading other peoples’ stories helps build empathy and understanding.

​
The Lev has brought together an amazing community of readers, connected online communities such as Girls at Library (GAL) and Mend by hosting over 20 author readings, talks, storytime & art hours, book swaps, workshops, monthly book clubs and other community events in only four months.
We’ve had the great pleasure of hosting artists, makers and writers such as Roda Ahmed, Mari Andrew, Trish Baden (Flores Lane), Katelynn Bartiromo, Danielle Birrittella (The Intuitive Voice),  Zinzi Clemmons, Lisa Cole (Hungry Right Meow), Yrsa Daley-Ward, Magdalena Edwards, Erin Falconer, The Fullest, Amy Harrison (The Little Studio LA), Aishwarya Iyer (Brightland), Mira T. Lee, Shira Lenchewski, MariNaomi, Laura Rubin (AllSwell), Yumi Sakugawa, Emily Stroia, Dydine Umunyana, Ally Walsh & Casey Wojtalewicz (Canyon Coffee), Jen Wang, Shinay Watts (Ellie and Sass), Stephanie Waxman, Meredith Westgate, Maude White, Women's National Book Association Los Angeles, and Fran Yang (Incandescent Bloom).
See our upcoming events here!

To prepare for opening The Lev pop up, I spoke with many booksellers across the country and even flew to a bookstore in Oklahoma City, Commonplace Books, to shadow owner Ben Nockels (to whom I am incredibly grateful) to learn about the journey of a community-focused bookstore. Many thanks to American Booksellers Association,  Books are Magic, Brazos Bookstore, The Dial Bookshop, Duende District, The Ripped Bodice, and Women & Children First for your generous advice ranging from the mundane to the magic of hosting our favorite writers. 

The Lev has served 600+ customers and processed more than 800 transactions but without the support of you and our community, The Lev will not flourish. Here are three main challenges we’re facing:


Real estate in LA is extremely expensive. To open, The Lev shared spaces with amazing brands (many thanks to Linus Bike and boy+girl for supporting The Lev). However, for The Lev to fulfill its mission of serving as a community bookstore, we need our own space. As such, we’re opening the search for a long term home to include all of LA. Our hope is to still stay in Venice or the surrounding area.

Financial solvency. Since rent will be high, The Lev will have tight sales goals. With The Lev membership program, we hope that our community will be loyal customers. However, The Lev plans to invest in a strategic marketing plan.

The unexpected.  A part of the funds being raised is dedicated to having an operations reserve.

With your support, I am committed to making The Lev a long-term establishment. My goal is to open a new storefront by September. I already have author events planned for the fall.

“Without specifically intending to, most businesses are patriarchal, and as such, some bookstores are. For me, reading books is a comfort — I wanted to create a bookstore for women so that we have a place for comfort and security.” - Miriam Chan, Ideal Woman
Miriam Chan is the owner and founder of The Lev. She knows what it takes for a business to succeed. Prior to The Lev, Miriam helped grow operations at startup company Civis Analytics from 13 employees to 140+, and led western state operations on President Barack Obama's reelection campaign in 2012.  Miriam’s love for books started at an early age. Her fondest memories are of her parents taking her to the county library and local bookstore as a child. Her absolute favorite writers are Maggie Nelson and Jean Rhys but is currently crushing on Elaine Castillo and Lisa Halliday. When not in the bookstore, visiting local bookstores or supporting local LA businesses, Miriam practices yoga and is a certified yoga instructor from her training at Venice's Love Yoga.








If you don’t already, follow our Facebook, Instagram and mailing list for community updates!
Spread the word about The Lev — encourage others to follow us and to join our mailing list.
Share our campaign — if you refer 10 people, you’ll get a $10 gift card to The Lev! You must do this through Indiegogo’s sharing tools
Purchase books through The Lev — we can make special orders!  Email hello@thelev.co


Our Venice pop up closes on Wednesday, June 27. As I campaign to raise funds, find The Lev at pop ups and markets around the city starting in July.
Thank you so much for checking out The Lev's crowdfunding page! Please support The Lev in building a community around women and books, and raising awareness of women and people of color writers helping them have a platform to educate and influence the younger generation in a powerful way!If you have any questions, don't hestitate to email me miriam@thelev.coWith love and heart,Miriam Chan

story:
Short Summary

Are you a nerd? I am! I grew up watching sci-fi, reading fantasy, and playing table-top and RPG games like Dungeons and Dragons. I love a good super hero movie and I get excited for comic-con or fan-expo every year.

I think we all have an inner nerd hidden in us somewhere just waiting to get out. Some make fun of us for our interests or obsessions, which is why we are making a place for Nerdkind, where no matter what your interests you can find your people and be yourself. Sports fans have sports bars and now nerds have nerd bars!

What We Offer

Great Food, Epic Fun!

Our Masterful Head Chef, Myles Hilliard has been in the industry for over a decade bringing new flavors and concepts to restaurants all over Southern Ontario. Also known as "Kodiak", he leaped at the chance to start up our restaurant as the only thing he likes more than food is nerd culture. He's cooked up a wonderful menu full of fun, tasty and nerdy items! Using fresh, local ingredients, you can expect to see things like The Dragon's Larder Meat Board (with a rich variety of local meats and cheeses), Targ Chops and Gagh (a sci-fi twist on Pork chops and German Spaeztle-noodles), and our mouth watering Merovingian's Cheesecake!

And that's not all! We have experienced Dungeon Masters who are hosting a massive Dungeons and Dragons campaign, playable by players old and new - your character can go on adventures from month to month, questing with different players as you discover the secrets of The Watchtower, meet the heroes who conquered the keep, and if you distinguish yourself, be recorded in the Tome of Heroes and painted into the Mural of Champions!

And the best part is - We offer a welcoming, friendly experience for nerds and geeks of all kinds - we love video games, science fiction, fantasy, comics and everything in between. No nerd cred required - no matter the depth of your experience, we think you're awesome for all the fun things that you love! Come in, play a board game, watch the ongoing D&D campaign, hang out with your friends, enjoy the food, it's all good.

Stay Nerdy, My Friends!
 

What We Need & What You Get

We are hoping that you will support our IndieGoGo campaign to help us launch our restaurant to shinning glory. We are planning to open in late October and with your support we can make a gathering place for fans of sci-fi, fantasy, comics, and games. Funds collected will help with the start up of the restaurant as well as the purchase of swords, board games and art. We are trying to raise $10,000, which is only a very small piece of the total cost of opening our restaurant. 

We have put together some great perks for you to choose from. I really want to buy them all myself! Some highlights are:

- Get exclusive access to our restaurant BEFORE our grand opening. We have a number of packages that get you in the door before we are open to the wider public. 

- Duels, yes you read that correctly. Challenge a friend to duel! Get a rapier sword fighting lesson and fight to first blood with a friend of foe. Resolve that issue once on for all. 

 

The Impact

By purchasing one of our perk you not only get the amazing benefit of that perk but the knowledge that you are helping to create a community that is open and accepting of every type of nerd culture. A place you can call your own. Join the nerd bar revolution!

 

Other Ways You Can Help

Not interested in one of our perks? Maybe you know someone who is. We would appreciate anything you can do to help get the word out!

 

Work at the Watchtower!

Want to work with us! We are looking for nerdy people to join our team!

Servers send resume and cover letter to:

Devin@WatchtowerRestaurant.com

Kitchen staff send resume and cover letter to:

Chef@WatchtowerRestaurant.com

Dungeon Masters looking for paid DM work apply to:

Devin@WatchtowerRestaurant.com

Investor Inquiries and Business Partnerships email:

Will@WatchtowerRestaurant.com
